title: Policies
description: Essential company policies, responsibility requirements, and regulations for safe operations

flashcards.question: What are your responsibilities in relation to drugs and alcohol policy?
flashcards.answer: Do not drink less than 12hrs before duty. Do not take drugs. Do not attempt to sign on for duty if under influence of drink or drugs. If caught drink driving tell depot manager immediately. Do not come to work with any alcohol or drugs with you. Report prescribed drugs to depot manager as soon as possible.

flashcards.question: How long does it take for alcohol to leave your system?
flashcards.answer: Time for alcohol to leave system - 1hr per unit for men, 1.5hrs per unit for women although everyone is different.

flashcards.question: How many units of alcohol are in different drinks?
flashcards.answer: Spirits (shot) - 1 unit, Alcopop - 1.5 units, Normal larger - 2 units, Bitter - 2 units, Cider - 2 units, 175ml wine - 2 units, Strong larger - 3 units.

flashcards.question: What are the limits on working hours?
flashcards.answer: No more than 12 hrs per shift. No more than 72 hrs in 7 consecutive days. Minimum 12 hrs rest between shifts (safety critical). Must not work more than 13 days in a row (must have 14th day off).

flashcards.question: What is personal sickness reporting procedure?
flashcards.answer: Must inform the depot supervisor at earliest opportunity if sick and not coming into work, do not wait until you are about to sign on for duty.

flashcards.question: What are the reasons for having rules and regulations?
flashcards.answer: To ensure everybody is working to a safe standard and to minimise risk of accidents, derailments or injuries.

flashcards.question: What is an error?
flashcards.answer: Error - genuine mistake, did not mean for it to happen e.g. misread stopping pattern, speeding etc.

flashcards.question: What is a violation?
flashcards.answer: Violation - where you know you have made a mistake and try to cover it up or you know the rules and deliberately break them.

flashcards.question: What are your responsibilities in relation to mobile phone policy?
flashcards.answer: Ensure your phone is switched off in an active cab. If using mobile phone for your duty ensure that you are in a position of safety and do not become distracted by the call. Do not use your phone if it could distract others whilst carrying out their duties.

flashcards.question: What are your responsibilities in relation to the use of personal electrical equipment?
flashcards.answer: No personal electrical equipment should be used in the cab while driving, includes radios mp3 players, earphones, headphones, computers, ipads, mobile phones. Managers can use Ipads to assess but ensure that you do not become distracted by them. Once trained on company Ipads then they can be used for your duties only while driving e.g. using T.A.S. ensure you do not become distracted.

flashcards.question: What are the risks of using personal electrical equipment?
flashcards.answer: Risk of distraction - not looking what you are doing, walking into unsafe areas, tripping / falling over, if using headphones / earphones will not be able to hear any warnings shouted or calls on GSMR.

flashcards.question: What are the requirements of the MFA policy?
flashcards.answer: If you are off 5 days (total) or 2 instances in a 13 week period. Or 10 days total or 5 instances in a 52 week period. Stage 1 - Informal chat with driver manager. Stage 2 - Formal chat with driver manager and union rep. Stage 3 - Formal chat with senior driver manager and union rep, (final warning). Stage 4 - Dismissal. Stage 5 - Appeal.

flashcards.question: Describe the care first policy?
flashcards.answer: Free phone number to offer counselling, information and advice on anything that is troubling you e.g. home life stress, money issues, bullying. Treated in confidence.

quiz.question: What are the reasons for having rules and regulations?
options: To prevent employees from making their own decisions
To ensure everybody is working to a safe standard and to minimise risk of accidents, derailments or injuries
To give management control over employees
To create documentation for legal purposes

A genuine mistake that did not mean for it to happen
A policy decision made by management

Only inform management if the medication makes you drowsy
